Author: $tefano.#3560
Content:
"no i was told paying a pool fee is stupid so i don't want to be stupid and i'll mine myselfbut on windows" @Resistor 
I would like to explain a little concept based on who belive in a project like KMD and not only for REWARD as you said 

1% of fee on my pool is 0,03 KMD  at every block , after 100 block my earn after a year and a half is 3 KMD, about 80/90 KMD at month if pool is lucky.
i have 4 servers with dedicated infrastructure for KMD some with more than 4 cpus and 8 GB that each  that costs more than 80/90 KMD at month.
Image when kmd was at minus than 0,4$ last year with half and half of blocks found...
Without considering time to dedicate on it.

A pool fee it's just like to say "hey man thank you for your time! "
Before talk please power on brain

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
@$tefano. I was the one that told him that, and please don't take it personally, but I have strong viewpoints against the usage of pools in the modern era (especially as it concerns centralization and miners seeking pure profits with no specific regard to the coin in question).
Conversely, from the standpoint of a purely economic scale, I 1/2 hope that **everyone** else joins public pools and I can grow 1-2% faster than they can.

Author: $tefano.#3560
Content: create a pool it's not a good job right now

Author: $tefano.#3560

Author: waterpark#6318
Content: that is a fair port. about your growing 1-2% faster though, i offer a counter point: the time you are spending trying to set up and maintain a node is a cost. it is worth exactly 1% of total earnings assuming you match a good pool's uptime. alternatively, if you put that set up time into earning money literally any other way, you could use that money to increase your hashrate far faster

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: @waterpark setting aside the things I do as me, setting up a private solo pool takes at max 1 hour (not counting chain download time), maintaining a viable node/wallet is something we all need to do in order to secure our personal finance anyway, and the more individual nodes that exist (miners or not) is the more decentralized the network becomes/stays

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: as far as my uptime, if I have no internet, I have no miners mining solo or in a pool

Author: waterpark#6318
Content: ah, i presumed your comment about pubkey coinbase tx was you working  a pool and it costing a fair amount of time

Author: waterpark#6318
Content: if you have the skills to get it up and running fast, go for it

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: and for the record, a solo pool is far less complex and need-intensive than that which is required to set up and maintain a public pool, so 1% is a vast over-estimate

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
`ah, i presumed your comment about pubkey coinbase tx was you working a pool and it costing a fair amount of time`
That's where the real irony comes in about my personal views, I'm working on trying to help set up the possibility to add some of the new Komodo assetchain features into public stratums (specifically `-ac_perc`)
It's a totally new type of transaction than what pools currently have available.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
Anyone mining KMD currently and mind doing me a quick favor?

working on documentation, and I need a sample of what this command produces:

```
komodo-cli getlocalsolps
```

It's an rpc call to query how many solutions per second your machine is currently calculating.

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: The downside is that opening them is an instant warranty void, but in the grand scheme of things if they still run after a week or 2 it's fairly likely that the warranty isn't going to ever be an issue (not that they'll usually actually warranty any unit that's been running for 160 days at full overclock anyway [unless you know how to kill all of the buffer logs before you send it back])

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: The upside is that, at scale, it makes a value tradeoff that any 1 $850 unit that would have needed warranty is offset by higher yields

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: At scale, +10% over the life is more than worth the 2-4% loss of lifetime

Author: bishop#9773
Content: According to Bitmain, OCing voids the warranty anyway, not sure how they would know unless there is some sort of saved log of the frequencies

Author: bishop#9773
Content: ...but, anyone not OCing shouldn't be mining

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: There are several reasons not to OC when your outfit is small enough or doing it as a hobby. I haven't looked into it with the Zs, but with the Ss one could actually underclock and get a better ROI per watt than possible with overclocking.

Author: bishop#9773
Content: Valid point, although I think the scaling of increased hash for additional wattage with the z9s has been pretty damn impressive. Quite surprised they didn't just factory OC them and drop one of the boards personally given that it is bitmain
